body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is possible to form an equation with the digits 1, 2, 3 and 4 using 2 operations:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1=2+3-4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your task is to form another equation using the same digits in the same order.  Apart from the equals sign,  is it possible to use just one operation? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You are free to change the position of the equals sign."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{n \choose 1234} = {n\choose 4321} \\ \dfrac{n!}{(n-1234)!1234!}=\dfrac{n!}{(n-4321)!4321!} \\ \dfrac{(n-4321)!4321!}{1234!(n-1234)!} = 1 \\ \Rightarrow n-4321=1234 \dots (\text{Since} 1234! \neq 4321! )\\ \Rightarrow \boxed{n=5555}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also there is a identity :"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Large {n \choose a} = {n\choose n-a} \\ \Rightarrow n-1234=4321 \\ \Rightarrow \boxed{n=5555}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            Nope. If WLOG "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k>q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then the number of ways to choose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" objects from a set of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has to be the number of ways to choose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" objects from a smaller set of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" objects, plus a few more (because they might be from the objects in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" but not "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":").

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I solved this in a sightly weird way"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left( \begin{matrix} n \\ 1234 \end{matrix} \right) =\left( \begin{matrix} n \\ 4321 \end{matrix} \right) \\\frac { n! }{ 1234!(n-1234)! } =\frac { n! }{ 4321!(n-4321)! } \\ n!4321!(n-4321)!=n!1234!(n-1234)!\\  4321!(n-4321)!=1234!(n-1234)!\\  \frac { 4321! }{ 1234! } =\frac { (n-1234)! }{ (n-4321)! } \\  (4321)(4320)\dots (1235)=(n-1234)(n-1235)\dots (n-4320)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From here we notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4321=n-1234"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the same as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4320=n-1235"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and so forth."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4321=n-1234\\ n=\boxed { 5555 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

Watch it, you will understand"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1 , 2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the line "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3x - 4y - 5 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  are on the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-plane."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the shortest distance between the line and the point?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(m , n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the line "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Ax + By + C = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the distance between the point and the line can be formulated as: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{|Am + Bn + C|}{\sqrt{A^2 + B^2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As a result, the distance between the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1 , 2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the line "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3x - 4y - 5 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" equals to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{|3\times 1 - 4\times 2 - 5|}{\sqrt{3^2 + 4^2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{|-10|}{5} = \boxed{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(4)"},{"type":"text","text":".(5)+3-2-1
Or 
(3)","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":".(4)+5+2+1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For some reasons the multiplication sign(Maybe it's the phone) isn't showing when I submit the answer, so I'll be representing themultiplication sign with a dot."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Utilizando o critério da divisibilidade de um número por 4 conclui-se que 1234525286 deixa resto 2 na divisão por 4,então basta analisarmos  os restos de x^2-y^2 na divisão por 4.
Observe que x^2 só pode assim como y^2, deixar resto 0 ou 1 na divisão por 4,então:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2-y^2 só pode deixar 0,1 ou 3 como resto na divisão por 4 oque impossibilita que haja solução para a equação do problema. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Rough translation","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using the divisibility of a number of criteria for 4 concluded that 1234525286 2 leaves a remainder when divided by 4, then simply analyzing the remainder of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x ^ 2- y ^ 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when divided by 4.
Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x ^ 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y ^ 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", let rest 0 or 1 on division by 4, then:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x ^ 2-y ^ 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"can only leave 0.1 or 3 as a remainder in the division by 4. So it is impossible that there is solution to the equation of the problem."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow\dfrac{\dfrac{2}{3}+\dfrac{5}{6}}{\dfrac{4}{5}-\dfrac{1}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"     "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\dfrac{9}{6}}{\dfrac{7}{15}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{3}{2}×\dfrac{15}{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{45}{14}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"     "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{3.21}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The single digit in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\square"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can't be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,5,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" because If you multiply a two-digit number by 1, you get the same number. If you multiply a two-digit number by 6, with last digit "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,3,4,5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", you'll get a number ending in 6,2,8,4,0 and this implies that this case is impossible .
If you multiply a two-digit number by 5, the last digit will end in 0, 5,. So this case is impossible too, (why?)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, the single digit in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\square"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2,3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Playing a little bit, you'll get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"54 \times 3 = 162"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Final review.-","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" We just only have the digits "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,3,4,5,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and we can just only use it once. If you multiply a two-digit number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", to get a 3-digit number, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must start with 5 or 6. But, then what happens?...  ( "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"65 \times 2 = 130"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", uff, you/we almost get it :)... )"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If you multiply a two-digit number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", to get a 3-digit number, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must start with 3,5 or 6. But, then what happens?...  If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" start at 3, what happens?...  If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" start with 5 , you'll get a three digit number starting at 2, and if you multiply a number by 4 with last digit "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,3,5,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" you'll get a number ending in 4,8, 2, 0, 4. For example, ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"53 \times 4 = 212"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":",uff, you/we almost get it :)...). If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" start at 6 , you'll get a three digit number starting at 2.  For example, ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"63 \times 4 = 252"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":",uff, you almost get it :)...). "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, we only can use "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" like single digit in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\square"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If you multiply a two-digit number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by 3, to get a 3-digit number, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must start at 4,5 or 6. A two digit number ending in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,4,5,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" multiplied by 3, you'll get a number ending in 3,6,2,5,8. This implies that the  two digit number can't start at 4 (why?) (Hint: Use hit, hit and trial..."},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"42 \times 3 = 126"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" uff, you/we almost get it).The  two digit number can't start at 6, either, (Why?) (Hint: this time don't use hit and trial) . Therefore, The only possibility is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"54 \times 3 = 162"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Guillermo Templado – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I have finished the proof, Chung, I would like your review. Effectively, the only possibilty is 162 "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Chung Kevin – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" be calm, I'll try to solve this question... But I used trial and error, too. It's necessary many times. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes. I used a lot of trial and error to show that no other values worked, so my solution wasn't exciting.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I still have to prove that there are no more solutions, that is, that 162 is the only possible solution to this problem...

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Wow, this was an old problem of mine. Thanks for adding a solution!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"My approach was to look at the possible "last-digit multiplications", like how you pointed out that the single digit needed to be 2, 3 or 4. After that, it felt mostly trial and error, so I wasn't surprised that this problem didn't become well-liked.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The thousandth's place is the place value at the third digit after the decimal point. Here, the thousandth's place is occupied by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
The above number can be expressed as follows:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \times 10^3 + 2 \times 10^2 + 3 \times 10^1 + 4 \times 10^0 + 5 \times 10^{-1} + 6 \times 10^{-2} + 7 \times 10^{-3} + 8 \times 10^{-4} + 9 \times 10^{-5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The digit multiplied with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^{-3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the digit at thousandth's place."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A decimal is a fractional number and is indicated by digits after a period which is called a decimal point."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Tenths have one digit after the decimal point. The decimal 0.8 is pronounced "eight tenths" or "zero point eight". It is equal to the fraction 8/10."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hundredths have two digits after the decimal point. The decimal 0.36 is pronounced "thirty-six hundredths" or "zero point thirty-six". It is equal to the fraction 36/100."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thousandths follow a similar pattern. They have three digits after the decimal point. The decimal 0.749 is pronounced "seven hundred forty-nine thousandths" or "zero point seven forty-nine"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There may be zeros after the decimal point. The decimal 0.064 is pronounced "sixty-four thousandths" or "zero point zero sixty-four"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"copypastefrom http://www.aaamath.com/dec44ax3.htm"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 is the thousands place
2 is the hundreds place
3 is the tens place
4 is the ones place
There is no such thing as oneths place
5 is the tenths place
6 is the hundredths place
7 is the thousandths place"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Also, thousands is referring to the numbers on the left of the decimal point, while thousand"},{"type":"text","text":"ths","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is referring to the numbers on the right of the decimal point. Don't get confused and do this simple mistake! You should read the question carefully to make sure you know which number the question is actually referring to.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first digit to the right of the decimal point is in the tenths place. Thus, the second digit to the right of the decimal point is in  the hundredths place, and the third digit to the right of the decimal point is in the thousandths place."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The third digit to the right of the decimal point (thousandths place) is 7."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"thousands and thousandths are 2 different terms. Thousands refers to the numbers at the left of the decimal point, while thousandths refers to the digits at the right of the decimal point.
In this case the numbers at the right of the decimal point are 56789. In decimals, the first digit from the right of the decimal point is called the 'tenths' and so by merely moving two steps right, we can find the thousandths. In this case, the answer is 7."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"just easy . 
1000 multiply with 1234.56789 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
1000  X   1234.56789 =1234567.8900"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Victor's mathematics teacher gave him a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \times 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" grid filled with the numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in an unspecified order, with each number appearing only once."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given any row"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\begin{array}{ | l | c | r | }
\hline
a & b & c \\
\hline
\end{array}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"or column"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\begin{array}{ | l | c | r | }
\hline
d \\ \hline
e \\ \hline
f  \\
\hline
\end{array}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"in the grid, Victor is allowed to perform the following operations:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Row:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c+k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Column:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d+k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e-k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f+k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" being a non-negative real number and that the numbers in the grid must always be greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given that it is possible to perform row and/or column operations such that all the numbers in the grid are equal to a positive real number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find the maximum value that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can take."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is nonnegative, the sum of all the numbers would decrease affer every operation. (Consider a row or column with sum "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a, b, c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the entries in that row/column. The sum after the operation will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+k+b-k+c-k=a+b+c-k<a+b+c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" )"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that the original sum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+2+3+...+9=45"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Clearly the sum must decrease in the end when all numbers are equal from the above, as at leaat one operation is needed.It is obvious that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an integer, so the largest possible is 4. I will post a possible arrangement in the comments."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            7 3 6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 9 8 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 2 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Operate on first and third rows with k=1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6 4 5 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 9 8"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 4 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Operate on second row with k=2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6 4 5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 7 6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 4 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Operate on first column with k=2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 7 6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Operate on second row with k=3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally, operate on last column with k=1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 4

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Consider "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 8 9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 6 7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 5 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Operate on first, second, third rows with k=4, 2, 1 respectively:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 4 5 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 4 5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 4 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Operate on first and third columns with k=1 for both:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 4 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence 4 is the maximum.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
